review_title: Work is rewarding, but there is no good leadership, low salaries, and no work-life balance
pros:
Working with people/community
No one day is the same and the helping people can be rewarding 
Employees are very friendly and welcoming 
They may occasionally let employees leave a few hours early on the day before a holiday (christmas/thanksgiving)
cons:
Turnover rate is incredibly HIGH (average of 1 to 2 years) 
Compensation is not good at all (considering all the responsibility, hours worked, and expectations of work) 
unprofessionalism from executive leaders and management (constant use of profanity and gossip)
Executive leaders like to put pressure and use fear to control people 
Weak infrastructure and small human resources department
Favoritism 
Management is very close minded and they love to MICROMANAGE employees 
Workload is huge (you do the work of two people, therefore burnout comes fairly quickly)
60hrs work weeks and they don't compensate your time or flex your time
very limited office space and not conducive working enviroment 
Offer very little training to employees and have very, very high expectations of performance
No room for growth or advancement (small non-profit)

review_title: Great front-line staff, HORRIFIC upper management.
pros: I met some amazing people while working there, who were truly dedicated to the work they did.
cons: Those amazing people I mentioned ALL left during my time there, and many expressed feeling demoralized, burned out, and humiliated. Several were seasoned professionals who were respected by their subordinates. Things I witnessed while working there: managers shouting at employees, using profanity and sexual comments that they thought were funny (honestly don't know how the executive director has not been sued for harassment by now), micromanaging to the Nth degree, expecting low-level staff to work 50+ hours with no overtime or comp time, and a general atmosphere of fear. There are so many other non-profits to chose from, please do your homework and really assess whether you want to work in this type of environment. Remember that no one should put up with abuse at work.

review_title: Decent experiences, but toxic, condescending environment
pros: Good potential for growth, good opportunities (i.e., conferences, meetings, group activities, outreach), staff members are passionate about the cause, amazing benefits, even in the first year of employment
cons: Unpleasant, arrogant attitude of executive director (that in turn feeds off on other staff members to make for an overall unpleasant work environment), absolutely zero room for error or learning curve for anything, which manifests itself to what the director deems as incompetent and untrustworthy work ethic, people take themselves too seriously, which manifests into arguments and accomplishing little, too many meetings

pros:
Identity, Inc. is a great organization to work for! The upper management expect the very best of you because the mission of the organization and the population that it serves demand it. 
As an employee serving youth and their families in Montgomery County, Maryland, you will find out that the organization is respected by other non-profits, county agencies and businesses.
While working at Identity, I found that the staff had the same "ganas" to work to better the community and most  people went above and beyond. I felt like the Directors of the organization are in the "fox hole" with you and work hard for the respect of the immigrant community.
I have 15 years of professional experience and Identity is where I learned the most. Candace and Diego have been the best supervisors in those 15 years. I currently work for a large government agency and only wish upper management here had the same drive and commitment that Diego and Candace have.
In these times of Trump, Identity continues to be an much needed advocate for the Latino community.
For any future employees, you will learn so much by working for Identity, but know that commitment and drive is required, and expectations for your work will be high.
cons: Most weeks were more than 40 hours of work, but if you have the passion for supporting and helping the community, you will not even notice the time you spend working at Identity.

pros: Identity has an excellent benefits package, we receive medical and dental paid for as well as a ton of PTO. Management always encourages using it. The staff are fun to work with and dedicated. The management also encourages hiring from within when a job is open.
cons: There have been growing pains in the last couple of years. There was some turn over. The management is working hard to hire the right people right away now.

job_title: Youth Development Specialist in Rockville, MD
pros: Passionate co-workers a all levels, great atmosphere, tremendous respect for the community we serve, hardworking and very professional.
cons: Not having enough resources to meet the need of those whom we serve sometimes means working a lot more hours. We also deal with very difficult cases. This sometimes leads to burnout and turn over.

pros: Identity does incredible work with at risk youth in the community and has a very unique and deep expertise with Latino youth.  Working here offers:  a chance to make a big difference with similarly committed and smart colleagues.  For most, the job becomes a calling.
cons: The need always outstrips resources.  It is hard to say no to kids, families and schools who reach out.

job_title: Youth Development Specialist in Gaithersburg, MD
pros: Mission-driven, diverse workforce, commitment to retaining people long term through staff development
cons: Low pay,  fairly regular turnover, and insufficient support for exposure to vicarious trauma.  At the time a lot of travel was required so I was more reliant on a car than id like to have been
